invention.title: Invention
invention.definition: A new product, system, or process that has been created.
invention.exampleSentence: At that time pasta companies were promoting a new **invention**, dried pasta.
invention.etymology: From Latin 'inventio', from 'invenire' meaning 'to find, discover'.

unspecified.title: Unspecified
unspecified.definition: Not stated clearly or exactly; not known or not said.
unspecified.exampleSentence: Here, the phrase at one point or another means at some **unspecified** time in the past.

idiom.title: Idiom
idiom.definition: A group of words established by usage as having a meaning not deducible from those of the individual words.
idiom.exampleSentence: And finally, the **idiom** to push the boundaries means to do things which challenge normal acceptable behaviour.
idiom.etymology: From Latin 'idioma', from Greek 'idiōma' meaning 'peculiar phraseology'.

boundaries.title: Boundaries
boundaries.definition: Limits of what is considered acceptable or allowed.
boundaries.exampleSentence: Unlike other Japanese foods, it's OK to push the **boundaries**.

acceptable.title: Acceptable
acceptable.definition: Able to be tolerated or allowed; satisfactory.
acceptable.exampleSentence: If you push the boundaries, you act in a way which challenges normal **acceptable** behaviour.

fresh.title: Fresh
fresh.definition: Newly made or obtained; not canned, frozen, or otherwise preserved.
fresh.exampleSentence: Well, some people buy them dried in a packet, others make them **fresh** from wheat or rice.

popular.title: Popular
popular.definition: Liked, enjoyed, or admired by many people.
popular.exampleSentence: there is little doubt that noodles are **popular** around the world.
popular.etymology: From Latin 'popularis', meaning 'belonging to the people'.

origins.title: Origins
origins.definition: The point or place where something begins, arises, or is derived.
origins.exampleSentence: From their **origins**, probably somewhere in China, noodle recipes were spread by traders on the ancient Silk Road.

recipes.title: Recipes
recipes.definition: Detailed instructions for preparing a particular dish, meal, or drink.
recipes.exampleSentence: From their origins, probably somewhere in China, noodle **recipes** were spread by traders on the ancient Silk Road.
recipes.etymology: From Latin 'recipere' (to take), originally used in medical prescriptions.

spread.title: Spread
spread.definition: To extend over a large or increasing area; to disseminate.
spread.exampleSentence: From their origins, probably somewhere in China, noodle recipes were **spread** by traders on the ancient Silk Road.
spread.etymology: From Old English 'sprǣdan', meaning 'to spread, stretch out'.

traders.title: Traders
traders.definition: People who buy and sell goods or services.
traders.exampleSentence: noodle recipes were **spread** by **traders** on the ancient Silk Road.

destination.title: Destination
destination.definition: The place to which someone or something is going or being sent.
destination.exampleSentence: At each **destination** along the road, people gave noodles a twist, adding different flavours and ingredients to create a new dish.

flavour.title: Flavour
flavour.definition: The distinctive taste of a food or drink or a quality that adds to the enjoyment of something.
flavour.exampleSentence: adding different **flavours** and ingredients to create a new dish.

ingredients.title: Ingredients
ingredients.definition: Any of the foods or substances that are combined to make a particular dish.
ingredients.exampleSentence: adding different flavours and **ingredients** to create a new dish.
ingredients.etymology: From Latin 'ingredientem', from 'ingredi' meaning 'to go in, enter upon'.

varieties.title: Varieties
varieties.definition: Different types or sorts of the same thing.
varieties.exampleSentence: two countries which have taken noodles and created exciting new **varieties**.

investigated.title: Investigated
investigated.definition: Carried out a systematic or formal inquiry to discover and examine the facts of (an incident, allegation, etc.) so as to establish the truth.
investigated.exampleSentence: The Food Chain, **investigated** how noodles spread from Asia through Europe to America.
investigated.etymology: From Latin 'investigare', meaning 'to track, search into'.

uncovered.title: Uncovered
uncovered.exampleSentence: They **uncovered** a surprising story: that pasta comes from noodles brought back to Italy by Marco Polo in the 13th century.

exotic.title: Exotic
exotic.definition: Unusual and exciting because of coming from faraway foreign countries.
exotic.exampleSentence: So, noodles were very **exotic** in the 1920s and 30s in the United States.

association.title: Association
association.definition: A group of people organized for a joint purpose.
association.exampleSentence: there was a new pasta **association** in America that wanted to promote the manufacturing of dried pasta.

promote.title: Promote
promote.definition: To support or actively encourage (a cause, venture, etc.); further the progress of.
promote.exampleSentence: a new pasta association in America that wanted to **promote** the manufacturing of dried pasta.
promote.etymology: From Latin 'promot-' (past participle stem of 'promovere'), meaning 'to move forward'.

manufacturing.title: Manufacturing
manufacturing.definition: The making of articles on a large scale using machinery; industrial production.
manufacturing.exampleSentence: that wanted to promote the **manufacturing** of dried pasta.
manufacturing.etymology: From Latin 'manu factus' (made by hand), later referring to industrial production.

meaning.title: Meaning
meaning.definition: What is meant by a word, text, concept, or action.
meaning.exampleSentence: noodles were popular because they were exotic, **meaning** foreign, unusual and exciting.

foreign.title: Foreign
foreign.definition: Of, from, in, or characteristic of a country or language other than one's own.
foreign.exampleSentence: noodles were popular because they were exotic, meaning **foreign**, unusual and exciting.

localise.title: Localise
localise.definition: To adapt (a product or service) to suit a particular place or market.
localise.exampleSentence: different chefs decided to **localise** these dishes.

slices.title: Slices
slices.definition: Thin, broad pieces of food cut from a larger portion.
slices.exampleSentence: adding new toppings and **slices** of beef or chicken, Japanese chefs created the noodle dish we know today as ramen.

gradually.title: Gradually
gradually.definition: In a slow, step-by-step way; by degrees.
gradually.exampleSentence: Something which evolves, develops and changes **gradually**.

response.title: Response
response.definition: A verbal or written answer; a reaction to something.
response.exampleSentence: Frank thinks that Japanese ramen continues to evolve – to develop and change gradually in **response** to new developments and ideas.

traditional.title: Traditional
traditional.definition: Existing in or as part of a tradition; long-established.
traditional.exampleSentence: Unlike other **traditional** food such as sushi, modern versions of ramen push the boundaries.

bank.title: Bank
bank.definition: A financial institution where people can save or borrow money, OR the land alongside or sloping down to a river or lake.

contextualMeaning.river: The land alongside or sloping down to a river or lake.
contextualMeaning.finance: A financial organization that provides various services, for example, accepting deposits and lending money.

bank.exampleSentence: I need to go to the **bank** to deposit some money. We had a picnic on the **bank** of the river.
bank.etymology: From Old French 'banc' (bench, money changer's table) and Old Norse 'banki' (sandbank).

school.title: School
school.definition: An institution for educating children or a place for learning.
school.exampleSentence: My younger sister goes to a small **school** near our house. Welcome to our **school**!

unusual.title: Unusual
unusual.definition: Not habitually or commonly occurring or done; out of the ordinary.
unusual.exampleSentence: Exotic means **unusual** and exciting because of coming from far away.
